entries.text: hey everyone
this is nick dearmardis teaching you
financial modeling
today we're going to be talking about
combining excel and python
using excel wings this is part of our
lecture segment on combining excel in
python
so we already explored how to use
pandas to do simpler integrations of
excel in python
now we're going to look at the full
possible connection between the two
using the excel wings library
so excel wings gives
us a nice convenient way that we can
use excel from python and use python
from excel
and go back and forth between the two
so you don't actually need to use excel
wings it's
it's built on top of uh
the microsoft com api
so that's an api that microsoft
releases so that other software can
interact
with microsoft office products
but it's kind of a pain to use
uh directly in python
i uh was doing that myself before this
xl wings library really became a thing
uh years back i had to

i was driving an excel plugin from

i would use python to

and keep re-running the plug-in
relaunching excel and all these things
so that was all possible without excel
wings but

easier had

when i had built out that project
so it is still under active development
just like
any of the um third-party packages that
we

every day there are improvements

so i keep saying there are different

different ways so
of two main categories of ways that we
can
uh integrate excel in python one of cell

the first here is manipulating excel
from
python so that's writing python code

in this course
and we're even focusing on a subset of
that
we're gonna focus on just bringing data
back and forth between excel
and python um and
orchestrating that from python

use this integration to do absolutely
anything that you would
be able to do in excel uh you want to
you know run run a create a data table
or
you know make a pivot table or whatever
anything that you can do in excel you
can do it from python
execute some python code and excel will
respond
in turn
the other main way that we can combine
the two is to run
python from excel so that's
using excel to orchestrate things and
running python code
and within that we have two different
categories here that are supported
in the excel wings library so one is
python as a vba replacement and the
other
is user defined functions so python is a
vba
replacement that means you know you have
an excel model
and you've hit the limits of what you're
able to do with basic cell you're
thinking okay i've got to write some vba
code
to accomplish what i'm trying to
accomplish well
this lets you write python code instead
and
just use that in place of using vba for
whatever you are going to do
so it basically gives you a vba function
run python which then will run python
code
in the background uh the other
main way of running python from excel is
using user-defined functions
and with user-defined functions
uh you basically create
a function in python
and you're able to call it from excel
so just like you have equals average in
excel
you can now have equals my function
and that my function is defined in
python code and it runs python code
it'll take the inputs from excel
run it through the python code and then
it will return
whatever you're returning it will take
that and bring it back into excel and
put the result in the cell so
really cool way of combining the two
and i think that um can really give you
the most power
um but those user-defined functions
are where uh there's still a lot of
active development going on
there's still um some bugs that they're

and it's
